poem:
Title: "Ode to Monopoly, A Reel Facsimile"

Pass the dice,
pass GO! No—
a celluloid mockery
in Robbie's possession. 

Banknotes folded 
into dreams. Yet—
the board remains flat, 
brittle houses standing unstepped—

An intention in Scarlett,
a jest in Thimble,
but no £200 collected—
the reel rolling unperturbed.

Oh! monopoly of images,
cold replicas in the toy box—
what game will be played next,
in this lonely room of illusions?
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Monopoly: the Movie? Pop culture has become a series of lukewarm adverts – and it’s all so very dull | Dan Hancox When it was announced last week that Margot Robbie will follow up the success of Barbie with a film based on Monopoly, my heart sank, did not pass go, and did not collect £200. Robbie’s production company will partner with Hasbro, just as the Barbie film was an initiative from rival toy company". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
news: Monopoly: the Movie? Pop culture has become a series of lukewarm adverts – and it’s all so very dull | Dan Hancox When it was announced last week that Margot Robbie will follow up the success of Barbie with a film based on Monopoly, my heart sank, did not pass go, and did not collect £200. Robbie’s production company will partner with Hasbro, just as the Barbie film was an initiative from rival toy company
